title: Jim Serdaris
text:
Jim Serdaris (born 1 October 1971) is an Australian former professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a>. He played for the <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a>, <a href="Canterbury-Bankstown%20Bulldogs">Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs</a>, <a href="Western%20Suburbs%20Magpies">Western Suburbs Magpies</a>, <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles</a>. He also represented <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League%20team">New South Wales</a> and played one game for the <a href="Australian%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australian</a> national side. He primarily played at .
Career.
Serdaris won the <a href="Dally%20M%20Awards">Dally M</a> "Rookie of the Year" in 1989. At the end of the <a href="1994%20NSWRL%20season">1994 NSWRL season</a>, he went on the <a href="1994%20Kangaroo%20tour">1994 Kangaroo tour</a>, the last Western Suburbs player to ever tour with the Kangaroos. He was selected to represent <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20state%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales</a> as a hooker for all three games of the <a href="1995%20Rugby%20League%20State%20of%20Origin%20series">1995 State of Origin</a> series and played his only Test for Australia in the subsequent series against New Zealand. Serdaris was a member of the <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League%20season%201996%23Grand%20Final">1996 Grand Final</a> winning Manly-Warringah team which defeated <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George Dragons</a>, 20–8. Although his Australian first-grade career came to an end in 1999, Serdaris returned to rugby league in 2002, joining French club <a href="Pia%20XIII">Pia XIII</a>.
